title: Will any 2020 California election results be altered by a cyberattack against a voting system?
preds: The California 2020 elections will not be altered directly by a cyberattack. This is largely due to the fact that because of the events of the 2016 elections the government has invested heavily in cyber defense systems. California also has a measure put in place to verify whether the votes were altered. However, seeing as the Presidential election already passed, there was no incident of a cyber attack. Therefore proving that no election results would be altered.
consensus since a lot of weeks
just due to history of elections with cyber attacks

(no change) Now that FOX is named in a suit there will be more people digging for some (slightly) plausible reasons not to fork over $. It might be dismissed since it is the media, but would one bet on that if you were in senior leadership?

This NPR article (and others) was published last November 2020, but due to lack of any new information or dubious results, plus the closing date, the suggestion is 0%. https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-2020-election-results/2020/11/12/934377227/no-evidence-election-was-compromised-cybersecurity-agency-says  https://fortune.com/2020/11/02/election-cyber-security-2020/  https://www.cisa.gov/news/2020/11/12/joint-statement-elections-infrastructure-government-coordinating-council-election

Ms. Powers acknowledged that all voter fraud allegations against Dominion Voting Systems Corp. and Smartmatic SGO Group have been made up completely and tries to save herself in a 1.3bn USD damage lawsuit filed against her, "saying that her statements about rampant voter fraud were opinion and legal theory and that “no reasonable person” would believe to be facts."
https://shepherdgazette.com/sidney-powell-information-for-dismissal-of-dominion-lawsuit/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Voting_Systems

(no change) If the suit against Powell isn't dismissed, then digging up some reasonable facsimile of some problems might occur to her legal team. The bar for something that almost passes the giggle test might be very low, as might the threshold for a yes with this question.
(no change) The DNI announcement isn't definitive, but definitely something to consider.
There is no news about this.

Cyberattacks have never been used before to alter election results that we know of (of course, if they're good we should never know!) But I strongly doubt that elections of any kind will be altered in the next couple of months.

Down 1%. Discovery process related to the DT inspired blather related to the two significant lawsuits by Dominion and the other company may uncover interesting things, but the time to resolve this queston is short.

Election security is very high in the United States and there was no tampering with the 2020 general election results. (https://www.npr.org/sections/live-updates-2020-election-results/2020/11/12/934377227/no-evidence-election-was-compromised-cybersecurity-agency-says) Given this high level of cybersecurity it is extremely unlikely that election results in California will be altered.

No. The voting systems themselves are tricky targets with all sorts of verifying mechanisms. Also they are widely spread out. Combine that with a new US Cyber Czar who knows what he is talking about and also Russia needing to figure out how to deal with a new administration.

Seems to be a developing story, though... "On Dec. 21, The Wall Street Journal said it had uncovered at least 24 companies that had installed the malicious software. These include tech companies Cisco, Intel, Nvidia, VMware and Belkin, according to the Journal. The hackers also reportedly had access to the California Department of State Hospitals and Kent State University."[...]
"Nicknamed APT29 or CozyBear, the hacking group pointed to by news reports has previously been blamed for targeting email systems at the State Department and White House during the administration of President Barack Obama. It was also named by US intelligence agencies as one of the groups that infiltrated the email systems of the Democratic National Committee in 2015, but the leaking of those emails isn't attributed to CozyBear. (Another Russian agency was blamed for that.)"
https://www.cnet.com/news/solarwinds-hack-hits-major-tech-companies-and-hospital-system-what-you-need-to-know/ https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/24/suspected-russian-hackers-made-failed-attempt-to-breach-crowdstrike.html
Even if this happened, the forensics necessary to make the claim are likely to take longer than the 1 May 2021 deadline

I'm going with a zero assessment on this question because, while I think it highly unlikely that the 2020 CA elections were cyber-manipulated to the degree it changed any outcome/totals, I find it even more unlikely that CA would be aware of it in time for this question to close, given the rate of attacks compared to the rate of detection. These are my three primary data points: 
Hackers attack every 39 seconds, on average 2,244 times a day. (University of Maryland) 
The average time to identify a breach in 2019 was 206 days. (IBM)
The average lifecycle of a breach was 314 days (from the breach to containment). (IBM)
Since the time from the presidential election to the close of this question is 184 days, less than both of the averages of 206 and the 314 days, plus the info from @juancambeiro on CISA's election confidence, leads me to my 0 assessment.

"Christopher Krebs, the nation's former top election security official, tells 'Axios on HBO' that President Trump is spreading disinformation ... [Trump] fired him for putting out a statement saying that the 2020 election was the most secure in American history ... Krebs had refused to co-sign — and in fact publicly contradicted — Trump's conspiracy theories that hacked computer systems flipped the election by switching votes from Trump to Joe Biden." https://www.axios.com/christopher-krebs-trump-2020-election-a40eec9d-a32a-4a04-824f-5ec13ba7f6e6.html Yet another implicit confirmation by the top election security official who oversaw the 2020 election that no votes were altered.
this is a nonsense claim which the courts will not accept

Up 1%. 40 CA counties use the Dominion system. I haven't followed the blather (tech term) related to this company, but future investigations might push some claims into a grey area. If so, what criteria does GJO use to resolve this question?

CISA has been very confident in its assessments. This certainly isn’t impossible but it sure looks unlikely. Changing votes, especially, is a more difficult proposition than just a generic attack to impact availability or confidentiality.

New statement out today by officials from the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and its election partners: "The November 3rd election was the most secure in American history. Right now, across the country, election officials are reviewing and double checking the entire election process prior to finalizing the result ... There is no evidence that any voting system deleted or lost votes, changed votes, or was in any way compromised." https://www.cisa.gov/news/2020/11/12/joint-statement-elections-infrastructure-government-coordinating-council-election
There is still no indication that this has occurred.

"Three and a half years of election security upgrades, training and government information sharing appeared to pay off on Election Day as voting unfolded with the usual technical glitches but no evidence of successful cyberattacks ... Even so, officials cautioned that the election process still faced serious cyber threats as it moved from the vote-casting phase into the vote-counting phase ... University of Michigan computer science professor J. Alex Halderman, one of the country’s most respected voting security experts, wrote on Twitter that 'the vote counting is an *even more* important area of vulnerability now, and will continue to be until the election result is clear,' because adversaries now have a clear sense of 'where they need to intervene to affect the outcome' ... But regardless of what happens next, surprisingly little happened on Tuesday" [1]. So there is still some risk of a cyberattack that aims to alter an election result — however, California is not one of the states where malicious actors "need to intervene" to affect the outcome, since it has already been called for Biden [2]. [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/04/initial-signs-point-to-surprisingly-hack-free-election-but-risks-remain-434094
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/11/03/upshot/network-race-call-tracker.html

(no change) An idea I alluded to yesterday: "While officials have warned all year about possible cyberattacks—and clearly Iran and Russia are already engaging in some—the worst-case scenarios of hackers actually changing votes seem unlikely. Instead, the biggest cyber threat is likely from groups pretending that they changed votes." quoted from: https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2020/10/23/election-nightmares-guide-430915

"White House National Security Adviser Robert O’Brien declared on Sunday that Russian hackers who were recently reported to have launched attacks on state and local governments 'can’t change votes' in the Nov. 3 elections." https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/25/obrien-hackers-votes-november-election-432268 Even if the Russian hackers *could* change votes, why would they do so in a solid Dem state instead of in swing state(s)?

We are told by the government (federal and state) that voting systems are secure.  Everybody is aware of the potential hacking by various state players such as Russia, China, and Iran, and presumably doing their utmost effort preventing this to happen.  I trust that California is rich enough and have the resources to implement mediation efforts.   Furthermore, CA is not a battleground state where votes are important in determining the outcome of a presidential election.  If I were a FTO, I would concentrate my efforts to Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.

There was one congressional district decided by 3% or less and 2 by 5% in 2018. Due to redlining and demographics, California politics is very polarized with most victories by margins of over 20%. If a cyberattack were to change an election result in most California districts, the results would be extremely scrutinized and research. The organization responsible for the attack will most likely brought to light and the attack would be too obvious to dispute. States and counties that have tighter margins are more likely to be attack than districts in CA.

"Microsoft has taken legal steps to dismantle one of the world’s largest botnets, an effort it says is aimed at thwarting criminal hackers who might seek to snarl state and local computer systems used to maintain voter rolls or report on election results. ... The fear isn’t that an attack could alter actual results, but rather that it could shake the confidence of voters ... Reporting systems or voter-registration sites are easier targets for hackers than the actual systems that count the ballots, which governments have worked to harden over the years." https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/10/12/microsoft-trickbot-ransomware/ This is probably a good example of the type of interference we're seeing in the 2020 US Election — there are many attempts to sow discord and otherwise cast doubt on the integrity of the election but few, if any, attempts to actually alter election results.

DHS in USA is warning of ransomware (primarily trickbot) attacks “could significantly disrupt the upcoming elections”. US cyber command (CYBERCOM) is conducting operation to hinder trickbot botnet during election (they can only hinder a few hours at time if I understand correctly). Have a longer report containing interesting info...
. China, Russia, Iran up to old tricks
. Registration data and voter history of ~10 million voters (mostly Michigan) available on dark net
. State sponsored actors exploiting vulnerabilities “resulting in unauthorized access to election support systems” however FBI and CISA assert “no evidence to date integrity of elections data compromised” I’m going up to 1% but still believe it will be disinformation and threat of disruption rather than actual successful attack.

In the event that a cyber attack happens or if the election results are contested claiming cyberattack, it's not clear from the question as to what availability of evidence really means. Even if there is evidence that cyber attack happened which affected the total count / election outcome, there will be a long drawn investigation to resolve this and given the time it took to prove the famous Russia interference / collusion in 2016 election, it's highly unlikely that this would be proven by May 2021. 
My forecast is based on the fact that historically there's no evidence of this event. While a cyberattack is likely, the probability of it affecting results is negligible and probability of this getting proved within 6 months is also highly unlikely.

I receive most cyber threat/crime reports as part of my job. Have yet to receive any credible threats re. Hacking of election in California. I did, however receive the following today which aligns with disinformation campaigns...
“Alleged Iranian interference operations aimed to disrupt U.S. Presidential elections
. Intelligence sources observing Iran-linked activity...
. Iran sees election as impacting its economic and social stability 
. This is attributed to Trump administration’s reimposition of sanctions on Iran which have resulted in increased levels of economic and social hardships and an increased threat of a direct military engagement with the U.S.
. Tehran views the re-election of President Donald Trump as leading to further instability and greater economic challenges
. Conservative Iranian elements also criticized a possible new administration led by former Vice President Joe Biden as one that will not alter attempts to isolate the Islamic Republic
. Intelligence sources claim Iranian covert disinformation operations relating to the U.S. electoral process were carried out using automated bot accounts and fake personas on social media (ex. “Endless Mayfly” campaign 
. Overt Iranian information operations have rapidly established programs such as English language “Palestine Files” which adjoined U.S. topics like Black Lives Matter and the death of George Floyd with that of pro-Palestinian and “anti-Zionist” movements.
. Such operations broadly contribute to Iran’s objective of deteriorating the U.S. government reputation 
. Iranian media groups like Press TV use investigative reporting and interviews with U.S. based persons on topics such as domestic politics and social developments to depict perspectives that support Iran’s interests
. Intelligence sources assess these efforts are specifically aimed at English-speaking audiences, primarily in the U.S., with the goal of lowering the audience’s confidence in the democratic process
. Cyber operations have also impacted the U.S. election space, showcased by reports of Iranian state-sponsored threat actor APT35 conducting phishing attacks against the campaign staff of President Donald Trump in June 2020.”
It goes on with further details but you get the gist... the above information did not come from the U.S. It is possible another state actor influenced it however (dis-disinformation?). Just because your paranoid, doesn’t mean they’re not after you!

First an attack would have to happen, it would have to alter the results, and, most unlikely of all, California would have to recognize and admit the attack. Regardless of the election outcomes I expect it will be contested. But admitting there was a hack would seriously undermine the system. Also, as others have said, why attack a non battleground state.

The quality of the first presidential debate and the press' reaction made me rethink my position. Enough trouble can be and is caused elsewhere, easily. Since California is likely to be neither one of the states with the closest races, nor one near the projected tipping points for the electoral colleges majority (1), I think it just is not worth the effort. And US domestic interest in keeping potential cyberattacs hushed up are substantial. (1) https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/pennsylvania/ ->states close to tipping point, states with closest races
Because of Air Gap rather unlikely.
This is a 50/50 question until the time factors in

Always possible, even if the “attack” is simply meant to so discord regardless of efficacy. I get multiple reports daily of (worldwide) cyberattacks etc but I get very few related to elections. Doesn’t mean they aren’t being attempted. As previously mentioned, disinformation is more efficient (unless an inefficient attack is meant as disinformation)
https://www.wired.com/story/election-threats-fbi-cisa-disinformation-hack-leak/

Cyberattacks are likely to be unsuccessful due to past experience from 2018 and current coordiation between local, state and federal government. Cybercriminals will likely shift their efforts to disinformation on Election Night in order to put the legitimacy of the election in to question. Sept 17, 2020- FBI- Worldwide Threats to the Homeland
Following the 2018 midterm elections, we reviewed the threat and the effectiveness of our coordination and outreach. As a result of this review, we further expanded the scope of the Foreign Influence Task Force (FITF). Previously, our efforts to combat malign foreign influence focused solely on the threat posed by Russia. Utilizing lessons learned over the last year and half, the FITF is widening its aperture to confront malign foreign operations of China, Iran, and other global adversaries. To address this expanding focus and wider set of adversaries and influence efforts, we have also added resources to maintain permanent “surge” capability on election and foreign influence threats.
We have also further refined our approach. All efforts are based on a three-pronged approach, which includes investigations and operations, information and intelligence sharing, and a strong partnership with the private sector. Through the efforts of the FITF.
https://www.fbi.gov/news/testimony/worldwide-threats-to-the-homeland-091720 "The FBI and the Department of Homeland Security’s Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warned Tuesday that foreign malicious hackers will likely attempt to spread disinformation around election results later this year."
https://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/overnights/517689-hillicon-valley-fbi-dhs-warn-that-foreign-hackers-will-likely "The San Mateo County Registrar of Voters Office gave KPIX 5 a tour of its security system and says it is working closely with the state and federal government to repel any cyberattacks launched by hackers or foreign country ahead of the 2020 election. The Registrar of Voters Office works with the FBI, Homeland Security, The Department of Defense and the California of Secretary of State’s Office to defend against cyberattacks." 
https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2020/09/08/san-mateo-co-voter-registrar-working-with-state-feds-to-repel-hackers-foreign-cyberattacks/
I think other states would be more likely targets
At this time it will appears that an attack that alters votes is unlikely. However, an attack that suppresses voter turnout or makes counting votes more difficult is very likely.

California votes primarily on paper ballots. 1% audit of the paper is required in all elections making it extremely unlikely that a hack would go unnoticed, and no election outcomes would be changed due to the ability to recount paper ballots.
It's a possibility.  I would be more concerned about alterations in a swing state, where it would be harder to detect, as it might be less expected.

this question is poorly defined, to me. What does 'results be altered' mean? Does it mean the election is swayed from D to R in a particular seat, or that 1 bad vote is tallied and later disqualified? If an election outcome is swung, it necessarily means vote totals were adjusted, or votes were moved from one person to another.  Swinging a particular seat is a much higher barrier to cross, while adding 1 bad vote into any small race (or simply switching 1 vote from D to R) seems plausible. I'm skeptical, overall.
It's possible - but why target California where an anomaly in results would be clearly seen?
In the unlikely event that there is a successful cyberattack - it likely will be caught promptly

This article doesn’t specifically address an attack but does outline measures to verify numbers etc.
https://www.wired.com/story/election-mass-voter-fraud-protections/

I receive multiple daily reports re vulnerabilities (real and potential) and latest attack vectors. Some very bright people behind these (in turn state actors like APT). And they are successful in monetization. But, in terms of elections, more bang for buck in misleading information...including potential voting hacks. Will look into more, but for now I’m going low at 1%. Wouldn’t California be odd - elections are usually wrapped up before their results roll in?

(1)  The odds are that people who know how to interfere with US voting results at a meaningful level are roughly as numerous as centaurs.   (2)  In California, all of this year's results have been easily predictable since about 1990, except for maybe the school board in Rancho Cucamonga.  (3)  So if any of (1) did exist, they wouldn't bother with California (except see Rancho Cucamonga, supra), but would instead mux about in Wisconsin or someplace worthwhile. (4) Staying at 1% to allow for the Rancho Cucamonga Effect.

While not a zero probability, I'm rounding down to zero. The idea of hacking the voting systems is what security expert Bruce Schneier calls a "movie-plot threat". It's something that the bad guys do in movies (or in the minds of unhinged politicians and  commentators), but not in the real world. The same outcome can be achieved with far less effort by other means.

The first two key considerations are the following: 
1) Who has the motive to launch cyberattack(s) on California's election infrastructure?
2) Who has the capability to successfully carry out such an attack?
I think foreign state actors that are hostile to US interests meet both of these criteria. In particular, I think Russia is especially likely to carry out such an attack given its unprecedented meddling in the 2016 presidential election.  -----
Next — has anything like this ever occurred? If not, is there a reasonable basis to think it will occur in this election? It seems like no voter data has ever been manipulated via a cyber attack, let alone have been outright altered. This was not even the case in the 2016 presidential election, when "... Russian hackers stopped short of manipulating voter data" [1]. This strikes me as being the result of geopolitical considerations — Russia surely knows that the cost to *actually* manipulating the results of an American election would be very high. So instead, Russia does what it does best: sow discord, cast doubt on the integrity of the election, and spread disinformation [2]. Russian state actors know that the costs to such activities are far lower than something as extreme as the outright altering election results or vote totals. 
Thus, I think a repeat of 2016-style interference is *far* more likely than cyberattacks that alter vote totals and/or election results. Indeed, the actions that Russia has already taken to interfere in the 2020 presidential race are very similar to their interference activities in 2016 [3, 4]. ----
Finally, even if a bad actor (in my view, probably the Russian state) *wanted* to carry out a cyberattack that alters vote totals and/or election results, could they do so? According to the AAAS EPI Center's Voting Technology and Security Program, "Paper ballots, marked either by hand or machine, are the most effective way to ensure that the votes cast in an election reflect voters’ intent. When every vote creates a paper trail that is routinely audited in a statistically-sound method, it provides assurance that votes have been tabulated correctly" [5]. So, basically paper ballots are the most reliable and robust method of voting.  And guess what — California uses paper ballots! As per California Secretary of State Alex Padilla: "Ballots cast in California are primarily cast on paper ballots. Historically, it has been asserted that paper trails associated with paper ballots allow for prompt detection of possible intrusions into the voting process. Therefore, voting systems that are direct record electronic systems must have the ability to provide a voter verified paper audit trail (VVPAT) for audit, recount, and manual tally purposes. Further, as a safeguard to ensure votes were accurately read and tallied, county elections officials are required to conduct a manual tally of one percent of the precincts as part of the official canvass of election results." [6] The use of paper ballots doesn't definitively preclude the possibility of tampering via a cyber attack, but it does make it *much* more difficult. ----
Overall, I think such a cyberattack this year is very unlikely against *any* state in the US. And even if such an attack did occur, why would Russia go through the trouble of launching a cyberattack against a state that 
1) has at least mediocrely secure election infrastructure, relative to other states [7] 
and 
2) isn't even a swing state that could decide the election? Moreover, as others have noted, even if such a cyberattack did occur it would have to be made public before May for this to resolve positively — this is yet another reason to lean toward a no. I don't think the probability of such a cyberattack occurring and being disclosed in this time frame is actually 0%, but I think it's closer to 0% than to 1%. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/07/us/politics/remote-voting-hacking-coronavirus.html
[2] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/russia-wants-to-watch-us-tear-ourselves-apart-fbi-official-says-ahead-of-elections-2020-02-24
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/10/us/politics/russian-hacking-microsoft-biden-trump.html
[4] https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/russian-hackers-who-disrupted-2016-election-targeting-political-parties-again-microsoft-says/2020/09/10/301dd5fe-f36c-11ea-bc45-e5d48ab44b9f_story.html
[5] https://www.aaas.org/programs/epi-center/voting-technology-and-security
[6] https://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/ovsta/security
[7] https://cdn.americanprogress.org/content/uploads/2018/02/21105338/020118_ElectionSecurity-report11.pdf#page=31
the arrogance of our politicians and computer people can't be underestimated

seems to me to be based on 3 probabilities (similar to @MRVDM12) (1) the probability of this cyber attack being successful in altering election results.
(possible, hence non-zero: https://media.defcon.org/DEF%20CON%2027/voting-village-report-defcon27.pdf)
(2) the probability of this cyber attack leaving behind some evidence 
(don't know, but judging by interests under (3), very likely because useful)
(3) the probability of this evidence being made public
(likely, as many parties are interested in this as an outcome; State actors have an interest in destabilizing the (international) public's trust in democratic institutions, via undermining the percieved reliability of the democratic transfer of power.
(4) the evidence being made public before the deadline (1st of May 2021).
(as this is unimportant for state actors in the long game of destabilisation, this reduces my estimate from 30% down to 10%.

Base rate on this one is 0%. Air gapping the tabulating machines and using paper ballots makes altering the results very difficult. Raise that ever so slightly because of the variety of levels of elections (POTUS to school boards) and variety of actors that might try (Russian govt-supported hackers to bored tech savvy high school kids).

In reality, this is a combination of four probabilities:
(1) the probability of this cyber attack being attempted
(2) the probability of this cyber attack being good enough to succeed, yet clumsy enough to leave behind some evidence
(3) the probability of this evidence being discovered before the deadline (1st of May 2021)
(4) the probability that whoever finds this evidence (FBI? NSA?) will make (some of) it public before the deadline Altogether it seems quite unlikely that all of these events will happen, even though each individual one is at least plausible.
As a large democratic state it may be an appealing target for state-level actors seeking to influence the election; however this is balanced by the robustness of its' state institutions.
California is a safe democratic state. If hacker will attack election system, they attack swing states.

(Initial forecast:) Can't completely rule it out. (Article excerpt:) "On September 22, 2017, it was reported that the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) notified 21 states that they were targeted by Kremlin-backed hackers during the 2016 election." (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Election_security).  To my knowledge no U.S. votes were reported to be altered (via cyber-attack) in 2016. (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/07/us/politics/remote-voting-hacking-coronavirus.html) At least in higher-profile 2020 elections, California may not be a top target: It is not a presidential 'battleground' state, there's no Senate election, and there appear to be few 'toss-up' House district races. (https://www.270towin.com/2020-house-election/) Election officials, private companies and the public are likely at least more aware of the possibility of cyber-attack. Some precautions reportedly have been implemented in Cailfornia: https://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/election-cybersecurity/, https://www.npr.org/2020/07/17/892044086/twitter-attack-underscores-broad-cyber-risks-still-facing-u-s-elections, https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2020/09/08/san-mateo-co-voter-registrar-working-with-state-feds-to-repel-hackers-foreign-cyberattacks/ California (in general) does not appear to use online voting (https://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/voting-info/ways-vote/), which can be a possible target (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/07/us/politics/remote-voting-hacking-coronavirus.html).
Think things will be secure but believe there will be numerous claims that attacks have happened.

I note that the question refers to a cyberattack against any voting system in a Californian election whether it be Federal , State or Local.
The immediate focus is on the Presidential election on November 3rd, but there are other elections to be held on that date.
Depending on the type of election will possibly determine the probability, source and likelihood of a cyberattack.
All elections are potentially susceptible to an attack and therefore the result could be affected.
Looking at the register of elections to be carried out in California in the remaining part of 2020, there appears to be just November 3rd, that is for the General Election, school boards, DA and Superior Court and possibly other minor appointments.
The Federal election appears to have postal vote issues that could be manipulated. Possible, but not likely due to an awareness, trained officials and a paper trail as dictated by Californian law.
School Boards could be hacked by tech savvy students. Is this possible? – Yes.
The District Attorney and Superior Court appointments could be the focus of criminal elements. Is this possible? Yes.
According to the findings of the referenced websites, local officials lack the skills or training to monitor malpractices, potential or otherwise.
The attacks themselves could be an attempt to distort results emanating from the system itself, such as voting lists/postal ballots, lobbying influential parties or creating rumours and innuendo via social media.
The result of the latter being a creation of a disillusionment and distrust in the system by declining to vote at all, which would affect the result of the vote.
If the result of any election held in California had been affected by a cyberattack, would it be discovered? Perhaps not and that is why 3%.
https://ballotpedia.org/California_elections,_2020  https://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/upcoming-elections/county-administered-elections/  https://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/election-cybersecurity/  https://www.lavote.net/docs/rrcc/Election-Info/scheduled_elections_2020.pdf?v=41
https://sacramento.cbslocal.com/2020/08/14/usps-election-voting-ballots-delayed-problems/  https://www.bushcenter.org/catalyst/democracy/zarate-cyber-attacks-on-democracy.html  https://www.idea.int/sites/default/files/publications/cybersecurity-in-elections-models-of-interagency-collaboration.pdf
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-47478865

Down 3% to be closer to the consensus. I agree no one will expect to affect the CA results, but some real patriots might not want to repeat 2016 with the fake popular #'s. —even if it is only to cast doubt (which I think the US IC has said) which makes CA more of a target than some forecasters seem to think.
California ain't Georgia or Florida.  So the odds of California's election results being altered as the result of a cyber attack are very low, virtually nil.

Although campaigns have been subject to cyber attacks (1), there have not previously been (afaict) cyber attacks aimed at any election which have been discovered to have altered the election results. Given the base rate, the difficulty of doing so initially, the difficulty of being detected and the low pay off of altering the election results in california I think this has a <1% of occurring.  *In presidential terms, california would require massive cyber attacks to alter the election results. In the state elections the expected returns are so low it would be very difficult to justify.  1/ https://www.ft.com/content/9de75c4a-331f-11e9-bd3a-8b2a211d90d5
2/ https://www.ft.com/content/b46a3b8e-053a-11ea-a984-fbbacad9e7dd
